anchor.surface_text: The sole point for determination in the appeal is wheth- er a widow in possession of her husbands estate in lieu of her claim for dower with the companysent of the other heirs or otherwise is entitled to priority as against his other unsecured creditors.

anchor.surface_text: The dower of a Muslim woman is a settlement in her favour made prior to the marriage companytract and is similar to the donatio propier nuptias of the Romans but is of such an obligatory nature that if it is number mentioned before or at the time of the marriage, it is presumed to exist to the extent of a proper dower amount.

concepts.interpretation: Dower is a contractual debt for consideration (submission of person), obligatory, becomes absolute on consummation, paid from husband's estate, no priority over other debts.

arguments.claim: A widow's claim for outstanding dower even when she is in possession of her husband's estate in lieu of her claim with the consent of other heirs stands on no better footing than that of unsecured creditors.

arguments.claim: No specific Quranic text or any other original authority on Muslim law supports that a widow's claim for dower stands on a higher footing than the claim of any creditor in respect of an unsecured debt.

arguments.claim: A widow by her lien does not have any priority over other creditors; mehr as a debt has priority over heirs but these are not affected by possession.

arguments.claim: Unless husband placed widow in better position by his act, her dower claim is unsecured debt with no priority against other unsecured creditors.

anchor.surface_text: It seems clear that unless the husband by his own act has placed the widow in a better position than his other creditors, her claim for dower is in the nature of an unsecured debt

arguments.claim: In administration of Muslim estate, funeral expenses first, then debts paid before division to legatees and heirs.

arguments.claim: Dower is a debt upon the husband to be paid out of his estate; obligatory settlement for consideration (submission of person), preference over bequests/inheritance but no priority over other contractual debts.

holdings.text: A widow in possession of her husband's estate in lieu of her claim for dower with the consent of the other heirs or otherwise is not entitled to priority as against his other unsecured creditors.

anchor.surface_text: The sole point for determination in the appeal is wheth- er a widow in possession of her husbands estate in lieu of her claim for dower with the companysent of the other heirs or

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consensus of authorities including Tyabji, Ameer Ammal, Maina Bibi; Quran silent on priority vs creditors; dower is unsecured debt without charge by husband; ranks pari passu.

holdings.text: Unless the husband by his own act has placed the widow in a better position than his other creditors, her claim for dower is in the nature of an unsecured debt and she has no priority of any kind against the other unsecured creditors of her husband.

anchor.surface_text: A careful examination of the various authorities on the subject shows that the proposition of law on this subject has been companyrectly enunciated in Tyabjis Muhammadan Law  1940 Edn.  in these terms  1 A widow

holdings.reasoning_summary: Adopts Tyabji's Muhammadan Law; no charge created; possession does not confer priority.

holdings.text: A dower debt cannot be given any priority over other debts on any equitable consideration or on the ground that there is something inherent in its very nature which entitles it to priority.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, there- fore, a dower debt cannot be given any priority over other debts on any equitable companysideration or on the ground that there is something inherent in its very nature which enti-

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dower is contractual debt for consideration; preference over bequests/heirs but not other debts; supported by Hedaya, Ameer Ali.

holdings.text: The above mentioned two Allahabad decisions do not lay down the law correctly on this point and the rule has been correctly laid down in Ameer Ammal v. Sankaranarayanan Chetty.

anchor.surface_text: Ameer Ammal v. Sankaranarayanan Chetty 1 a Bench of the Madras High Court held that a claim for unpaid dower constitutes a debt payable pari passu with the demands of other creditors and is number a preferential charge on the estate.

precedents.cited_proposition: a claim for unpaid dower constitutes a debt payable pari passu with the demands of other creditors and is not a preferential charge on the estate

precedents.citation: Maina Bibi v. Chaudhri Vakil Ahmad 2

anchor.surface_text: Maina Bibi v. Chaudhri Vakil Ahmad 2 it was held that where the widow is number in the position of a se- cured creditor and is otherwise in possession of the hus- bands estate with the companysent of the heirs, she is entitled

precedents.case_name: Maina Bibi v. Chaudhri Vakil Ahmad
precedents.cited_proposition: where the widow is not in the position of a secured creditor and is otherwise in possession of the husbands estate with the consent of the heirs, she is entitled to retain possession of it until her dower debt is satisfied

precedents.citation: Meer Meher Ally v. Mst. Amanee 3

anchor.surface_text: Meer Meher Ally v. Mst. Amanee 3 it was held that the lien of the widow over the property in her possession is number a lien in the ordinary legal sense of the term and that a claim for dower is in the same position as that of any other ordinary creditor and ranks pari passu with them

precedents.case_name: Meer Meher Ally v. Mst. Amanee
precedents.cited_proposition: the lien of the widow over the property in her possession is not a lien in the ordinary legal sense of the term and that a claim for dower is in the same position as that of any other ordinary creditor and ranks pari passu with them

anchor.surface_text: Maina Bibi v. Wasi Ahmad 4 it was held that she has numberright of possession against the creditors, number being a secured creditor herself.

precedents.cited_proposition: she has no right of possession against the creditors, not being a secured creditor herself
precedents.cited_holding: she cannot set up any such right of possession against creditors claiming to have the debts owing to them from the husband satisfied out of the estate. She is number a secured creditor her claim for her dower debt ranks equally with the claims of other creditors of her husband

anchor.surface_text: Hamira Bibi v. Zubaida Bibi 1 it was observed that dower ranks as a debt and the wife is entitled along with the other creditors to have it satisfied on the death of the husband out of his estate. Her right, however, is numbergreater than that of any other unsecured creditor.

precedents.cited_proposition: dower ranks as a debt and the wife is entitled along with the other creditors to have it satisfied on the death of the husband out of his estate. Her right, however, is not greater than that of any other unsecured creditor

precedents.citation: Imtiaz Begum v. Abdul Karim Khan ,2

anchor.surface_text: Imtiaz Begum v. Abdul Karim Khan ,2 the same view was expressed. In para. 295 Mr. Mulla in his book on Muhammadan Law has adopted the view that dower ranks as a debt

precedents.case_name: Imtiaz Begum v. Abdul Karim Khan

precedents.citation: Kulsum Bibi v. Shiam Sunder Lal 3

anchor.surface_text: Kulsum Bibi v. Shiam Sunder Lal 3 , in which it was held that a widow in possession of her husbands estate is entitled as against the other heirs of her husband and as against the creditors to retain possession until her dower is satisfied.

precedents.case_name: Kulsum Bibi v. Shiam Sunder Lal
precedents.cited_proposition: a widow in possession of her husbands estate is entitled as against the other heirs of her husband and as against the creditors to retain possession until her dower is satisfied

precedents.citation: Mst. Ghafooran v. Ram Chandra Das 4

anchor.surface_text: Mst. Ghafooran v. Ram Chandra Das 4 by a single Judge. It was said that her possession companyld number be disturbed till her dower debt was satisfied.

precedents.case_name: Mst. Ghafooran v. Ram Chandra Das
precedents.cited_proposition: the same view had been taken earlier... her possession could not be disturbed till her dower debt was satisfied

anchor.surface_text: Mohamed Turabuddin v. Yasin Begum 5 a Bench. of the Hyderabad High Court held that the claim of a widow for dower was in the nature of a secured debt.

precedents.cited_proposition: the claim of a widow for dower was in the nature of a secured debt

anchor.surface_text: Wahidunnissa Begum v. Yasin Begum 6 it was pointed out that the claim of the widow for dower does number create any interest or charge on the property and that the position of a widow is number only that of a creditor where her dower remains unpaid but also of an heir.

precedents.cited_proposition: the claim of the widow for dower does not create any interest or charge on the property and that the position of a widow is not only that of a creditor where her dower remains unpaid but also of an heir

anchor.surface_text: Ameer Arereal v. Sankaranarayanan Chetty 1 . There is numberhing repugnant or inequitable according to the principles of Muhammadan Law in the estate of a deceased Muslim being rateably distributed between the unsecured creditors.

precedents.cited_proposition: the rule has been correctly laid down

edges.explanation: Issue i1 concerns priority of widow's dower claim against other unsecured creditors, addressing the unsecured creditor concept c5
The issue i1 questions whether the widow is entitled to priority akin to a secured creditor, directly addressing the concept of whether she qualifies as UNLISTED_SECURED_CREDITOR.
Argument a12 explicitly cites and relies on precedent p1 (Ameer Ammal v. Sankaranarayanan Chetty) for the proposition that dower is payable pari passu

Precedent p1 explicitly states 'a claim for unpaid dower constitutes a debt payable pari passu with the demands of other creditors', which directly establishes the concept c7 of UNLISTED_PARIPASSU 'Pari Passu Dower debt payable equally with other creditors' demands'
Precedent p1 supports holding h3 as it establishes no preferential status for dower, only pari passu
Precedent p1 addresses issue i1 by establishing pari passu treatment denying priority
Precedent p10 holding dower creates no charge or interest supports concept c4 that lien gives no creditor priority.
Precedent p10 supports holding h1 by establishing no proprietary interest from dower claim.
p2 Maina Bibi cited in a13 for pari passu ranking.
Precedent p2 widow not secured creditor supports h1 no priority.
p3 Meer Meher Ally cited in a13.
p3 lien not ordinary sense supports no priority in h1.
p4 no right of possession against creditors supports h1.
p5 dower as debt with creditors supports a6 no priority by possession.
p5 dower debt with other creditors supports h1 pari passu.
